required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Mineral Trioxide Aggregate Pulpotomy in Primary Maxillary Incisors
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective Outcome Investigation of Mineral Trioxide Aggregate Pulpotomy in Primary Maxillary Incisors

brief_summary.textblock: The objective of this investigation is to compare the clinical and radiographic outcomes of pulpotomies done using mineral trioxide aggregate (MTA) dental cement and the root canal/zinc oxide and eugenol (RCT/ZOE) technique in primary maxillary incisors.

detailed_description.textblock: The primary maxillary incisors are important in masticatory function, occlusal development, articulation and self-esteem. Cariously exposed vital pulps of primary incisors require pulp treatment to avoid infection, pain and premature tooth loss. Unfortunately, there is a paucity of investigations of maxillary incisor pulp treatment.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment

secondary_outcome.measure: Presence of a number of clearly defined radiographic and clinical signs
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At 1 and 2 years after the procedure

arm_group.description: Children randomized to this arm will undergo a mineral trioxide aggregate (MTA) pulpotomy after hemostasis is achieved using ferric sulfate (FS).
Children randomized to this group will undergo the root canal/zinc oxide and eugenol (RCT/ZOE) technique.

intervention.intervention_name: Root canal/zinc oxide and eugenol (RCT/ZOE) technique
intervention.description: After complete removal of all caries, if a pulp exposure is detected the pulp chamber will be opened and the pulp tissue removed. The canal will be irrigated with water and then filled with non-reinforced ZOE.

After complete removal of all caries, if a pulp exposure is detected the pulp chamber will be opened and vital coronal pulp to a depth of 2mm below free gingival margin will be removed. A solution of ferric sulfate will be applied to the amputated pulp surface and then flushed with water. MTA paste is then used to cover over the exposed amputated pulp surface.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- children with one or more carious primary maxillary incisors where removal of dental caries will likely to produce a vital pulp exposure
- reside in the GTA at time of inclusion
- English-speaking
Exclusion Criteria:
- clinical or radiographic evidence of pulp degeneration (such as internal/external root resorption and/or periapical bone destruction or swelling)
- radiographic evidence of physiological root resorption
- possibility of proper restoration of the tooth
- maxillary incisors present with an associated swelling

overall_official.affiliation: The Hospital for Sick Children, Toronto Canada
